conclusion: The goal is to determine the velocity v of the ions after passing through the velocity selector and the charge-to-mass ratio of the ions selected by the magnetic analyzer.

The velocity selector consists of crossed electric and magnetic fields. The electric field E is directed vertically upwards, and the magnetic field B is directed outward perpendicular to the plane of the paper.
Ions enter the velocity selector horizontally, along the positive x-direction.
The forces on an ion with charge q and velocity v are: Electric force: F_E = q E, Magnetic force: F_B = q v B (-j).
For the ion to pass through the velocity selector undeflected, the net force in the y-direction must be zero, leading to v = E/B.
The magnetic analyzer is a quarter-circular ring with inner radius R1 and outer radius R2. The magnetic field B in this region is directed outward.
Ions enter at point M and exit at point N, following a circular path due to the magnetic force.
For an ion with mass m, charge q, and velocity v, the magnetic force provides the centripetal force for circular motion, leading to q/m = v/(B R).
Substitute v = E/B from Step 1 to get q/m = E/(B^2 R).
Assume R is the average radius of the quarter-circular ring: R = (R1 + R2)/2.
The charge-to-mass ratio selected by the magnetic analyzer is q/m = E/(B^2 ((R1 + R2)/2)).
The problem provides details about the deflection system and wafer, but the question specifically asks for v and q/m.
When no fields are applied in the deflection system, ions travel vertically and hit point O.
With fields on, the ions are deflected, but the deflection angles are small, and we donâ€™t need to calculate the deflection for the main question.
The velocity of the ions after passing through the velocity selector is v = E/B.
The charge-to-mass ratio of the ions selected by the magnetic analyzer is q/m = 2E/(B^2 (R1 + R2)).
